intro: Tanaecium parasiticum, commonly known as the parasitic tanaecium, is a hemiparasitic plant that derives some of its nutrients from host plants. It belongs to the family Orobanchaceae, which includes many other parasitic species. The plant typically lacks chlorophyll and relies on its host for water and minerals, while performing photosynthesis using limited chlorophyll. It often grows on the stems or roots of other plants, forming a symbiotic relationship. Its small, inconspicuous flowers are usually white or pale in color, and it is found in various regions of South America.
